title: Fraction Calculator
description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide fractions with step-by-step solutions. Convert fractions to decimals, percentages, and mixed numbers. Simplify fractions to lowest terms instantly.

meta.title: Fraction Calculator - Add, Subtract, Multiply & Divide Fractions
meta.description: Free online fraction calculator. Add, subtract, multiply, divide fractions with step-by-step solutions. Convert fractions to decimals and percentages. Simplify fractions instantly.
meta.keywords: fraction calculator, add fractions, subtract fractions, multiply fractions, divide fractions, simplify fractions, mixed numbers, fraction to decimal, fraction converter

add.label: Add
add.description: Add two fractions together. The calculator finds the common denominator and shows each step of the calculation.

subtract.label: Subtract
subtract.description: Subtract one fraction from another. Works with proper fractions, improper fractions, and mixed numbers.

multiply.label: Multiply
multiply.description: Multiply two fractions. Simply multiply numerators together and denominators together, then simplify.

divide.label: Divide
divide.description: Divide one fraction by another. The calculator flips the second fraction and multiplies.

simplify.label: Simplify
simplify.description: Reduce a fraction to its lowest terms by finding the greatest common divisor (GCD) of the numerator and denominator.

convert.label: Convert
convert.description: Convert a fraction to decimal, percentage, mixed number, or improper fraction format.

disclaimer.text: This calculator provides mathematical calculations for educational and informational purposes. Always verify important calculations.
disclaimer.note: Results are automatically simplified to lowest terms. Decimal values may be rounded for display.

seo.whatIsContent: A fraction calculator is a mathematical tool that helps you perform arithmetic operations with fractions quickly and accurately. Fractions are used in everyday life—from cooking and construction to finance and science. Our calculator supports all basic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division), simplification to lowest terms, and conversion between different formats. Each calculation includes step-by-step solutions to help you understand the process.
seo.operationsIntro: Our fraction calculator provides six powerful operations:
seo.operation1: Addition – Add fractions with different denominators using LCD (Least Common Denominator)
seo.operation2: Subtraction – Subtract fractions with step-by-step solutions
seo.operation3: Multiplication – Multiply numerators and denominators directly
seo.operation4: Division – Flip and multiply (multiply by reciprocal)
seo.operation5: Simplification – Reduce fractions to lowest terms using GCD
seo.operation6: Conversion – Convert between decimals, percentages, mixed numbers, and improper fractions
seo.benefit1: Step-by-step solutions – Understand how each answer is calculated
seo.benefit2: Multiple formats – Work with proper fractions, improper fractions, and mixed numbers
seo.benefit3: Automatic simplification – Results are always reduced to lowest terms
seo.benefit4: Instant conversions – See decimal and percentage equivalents immediately
seo.benefit5: Free and unlimited – Calculate as many fractions as you need at no cost
seo.howToUseTitle: How to Use the Fraction Calculator
seo.howToUseStep1: Select the operation you want to perform (add, subtract, multiply, divide, simplify, or convert)
seo.howToUseStep2: Enter the numerator and denominator for the first fraction. Optionally add a whole number for mixed numbers.
seo.howToUseStep3: For operations requiring two fractions, enter the second fraction
seo.howToUseStep4: View the result along with decimal and percentage equivalents
seo.howToUseStep5: Review the step-by-step solution to understand the calculation process
seo.formula4: a/b ÷ c/d = a/b × d/c = (a × d) / (b × c)
seo.tip1: Always simplify your final answer by dividing both numerator and denominator by their GCD
seo.tip2: When adding or subtracting, find the LCD (Least Common Denominator) first
seo.tip3: To divide fractions, flip the second fraction and multiply
seo.tip4: Mixed numbers can be converted to improper fractions: (whole × denominator + numerator) / denominator
seo.tip5: A fraction equals its decimal when you divide the numerator by the denominator
seo.faq1Question: How do I add fractions with different denominators?
seo.faq1Answer: To add fractions with different denominators, first find the Least Common Denominator (LCD). Convert each fraction to an equivalent fraction with the LCD, then add the numerators while keeping the denominator. For example, 1/2 + 1/3: LCD is 6, so 3/6 + 2/6 = 5/6.
seo.faq2Answer: A mixed number combines a whole number with a proper fraction. For example, 2 3/4 means 2 whole units plus 3/4. To calculate with mixed numbers, convert them to improper fractions first: 2 3/4 = (2×4 + 3)/4 = 11/4.
seo.faq3Question: How do I simplify a fraction?
seo.faq3Answer: To simplify a fraction, find the Greatest Common Divisor (GCD) of the numerator and denominator, then divide both by this number. For example, to simplify 12/18: GCD of 12 and 18 is 6, so 12/18 = 2/3.
seo.faq4Answer: An improper fraction has a numerator larger than or equal to its denominator, like 7/4 or 5/5. These can be converted to mixed numbers: 7/4 = 1 3/4. Despite the name, improper fractions are perfectly valid and often easier to use in calculations.
seo.faq5Question: How do I convert a fraction to a decimal?
seo.faq5Answer: Divide the numerator by the denominator. For example, 3/4 = 3 ÷ 4 = 0.75. Some fractions create repeating decimals, like 1/3 = 0.333... (repeating).
seo.faq6Question: How do I convert a fraction to a percentage?
seo.faq6Answer: Convert the fraction to a decimal (divide numerator by denominator), then multiply by 100. For example, 3/4 = 0.75 = 75%. Alternatively, multiply the fraction by 100: (3/4) × 100 = 75%.
seo.faq7Question: Why do I need to flip the second fraction when dividing?
seo.faq7Answer: Dividing by a fraction is the same as multiplying by its reciprocal. The reciprocal of a/b is b/a. So a/b ÷ c/d = a/b × d/c. This rule makes division straightforward once you understand it.
seo.faq8Question: What is the LCD and how do I find it?
seo.faq8Answer: LCD stands for Least Common Denominator—the smallest number that both denominators divide into evenly. Find it by listing multiples of each denominator until you find a common one, or calculate LCM (Least Common Multiple). For 1/3 and 1/4, the LCD is 12.
